G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential tenancy in Massachusetts includes a statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, which provides in pertinent part that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly” interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises by any act or omission.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 20.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Housing Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3 and 20, because this action concerns residential landlord–tenant relations, conditions at a residential dwelling, and alleged violations of tenants’ statutory rights.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court because the Premises are located in Roxbury, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Division of the Housing Court Department. See G.L. c. 185C, § 3.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The State Sanitary Code, promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, requires that residential premises be maintained in safe and sanitary condition free from chronic dampness or water penetration. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.550, and related provisions regarding water, structural integrity, and prevention of moisture and related hazards.

105 C.M.R. 410.500.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, requires that residential premises be maintained in safe and sanitary condition free from chronic dampness or water penetration. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.550, and related provisions regarding water, structural integrity, and prevention of moisture and related hazards.

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, requires that residential premises be maintained in safe and sanitary condition free from chronic dampness or water penetration. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.550, and related provisions regarding water, structural integrity, and prevention of moisture and related hazards.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, requires that residential premises be maintained in safe and sanitary condition free from chronic dampness or water penetration. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.550, and related provisions regarding water, structural integrity, and prevention of moisture and related hazards.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant’s adverse treatment of Plaintiff and decision not to renew the tenancy, following Plaintiff’s report of code violations, is consistent with retaliatory conduct and coercive interference with Plaintiff’s statutory rights. See G.L. c. 186, § 18 (prohibiting retaliation for tenant’s contact with housing inspectors); Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983) (retaliatory actions by landlord after tenant complaints can violate statutory tenant protections and quiet enjoyment).

Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a landlord’s failure to maintain leased premises in a habitable and code‑compliant condition, especially after notice of serious defects, can constitute an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway (a concurrence/dissent) focuses on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of code violations on rent and the landlord’s repair obligations. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14, or articulate that failure to maintain habitable, code‑compliant premises constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment. Massachusetts’ modern quiet‑enjoyment/conditions doctrine comes from other cases; this opinion is about contract/warranty remedies and statutory code‑enforcement, not quiet enjoyment as such.
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.relevant_excerpt: “The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally … and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him. … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would … hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a landlord’s failure to maintain leased premises in a habitable and code‑compliant condition, especially after notice of serious defects, can constitute an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) focuses on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of housing code violations on rent and eviction, not on G.L. c. 186, §14 or the concept of unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. Nowhere does it discuss "quiet enjoyment" or characterize a landlord’s failure to maintain habitable, code‑compliant premises as an unlawful interference with that covenant. The case is important for habitability and rent‑withholding doctrine, but it is not authority for the specific quiet‑enjoyment proposition stated.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally, (b) that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations, and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him.”

Dorgan v. Loukas, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 705.raw_text: Dorgan v. Loukas, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 705 (2011)
Dorgan v. Loukas, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 705.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a landlord’s failure to maintain leased premises in a habitable and code‑compliant condition, especially after notice of serious defects, can constitute an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Dorgan v. Loukas, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 705.support_reasoning: The opinion in Dorgan v. Loukas is a criminal case about suppression of statements under Miranda and the sufficiency of evidence in a murder prosecution. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant law, habitability, building code compliance, or interference with quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about Massachusetts landlords’ duties regarding habitable, code‑compliant premises and quiet enjoyment.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 705.relevant_excerpt: In reviewing a judge’s ruling on a motion to suppress, we accept the “judge’s subsidiary findings of fact absent clear error, but conduct an independent review of the judge’s ultimate findings and conclusions of law.” Commonwealth v. Washington, 449 Mass. 476, 480 (2007). The judge was correct to deny the defendant’s motion to suppress as to the first and third statements, but he erred in failing to suppress the second statement: “The dude hit us.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (memorandum)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a landlord’s failure to maintain leased premises in a habitable and code‑compliant condition, especially after notice of serious defects, can constitute an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service required by the State Sanitary Code—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of the landlord’s financial inability. The court explicitly ties the failure to meet code‑based heating obligations to unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment and treats such conditions as seriously impairing the character and value of the leased premises. This directly supports the proposition that non‑habitable, non‑code‑compliant conditions after notice can violate quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750[B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Massachusetts, a landlord’s “omission” can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment when it foreseeably and substantially interferes with the tenant’s use of the premises. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718–719 (landlord liable for interference by failing to take steps within his control); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 851–852.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects any strict malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction and states that a breach of quiet enjoyment may arise from what the landlord "failed to do" when the interference is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct and is within the landlord’s control. The court holds the landlord liable based on his omission in failing to control the noise from the lounge, which foreseeably and substantially interfered with the tenants’ use and led to constructive eviction. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s omission can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent… To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord… and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction…"

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.proposition: In Massachusetts, a landlord’s “omission” can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment when it foreseeably and substantially interferes with the tenant’s use of the premises. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718–719 (landlord liable for interference by failing to take steps within his control); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 851–852.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the standard for liability under the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment statute and holds that a landlord’s failure to act (an omission) can violate § 14 when the landlord has notice or reason to know of the problem and fails to take appropriate corrective measures, and when the interference is the natural and probable (thus foreseeable) consequence of that failure. The court characterizes such failures to repair known defects as omissions that can breach quiet enjoyment, making Al‑Ziab proper authority for the proposition that a landlord’s omission may constitute a breach when it foreseeably and substantially interferes with the tenant’s use.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ … Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures… We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”}

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when a landlord “seriously interferes with the tenant’s ability to use and enjoy the leased premises,” including by acts of harassment, intimidation, or sustained failure to correct defective conditions after notice. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–104; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 284–285.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from “serious interference” with their tenancy that impairs the character and value of the leasehold, and applies this standard to the landlord’s omissions in failing to address criminal drug activity in common areas. The court holds that if the landlord “stood idle” and failed to take available measures to remove unlawful actors, thereby seriously interfering with tenants’ use of common areas, it may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that serious interference—including sustained failure to correct conditions after notice—can violate the covenant.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development … then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when a landlord “seriously interferes with the tenant’s ability to use and enjoy the leased premises,” including by acts of harassment, intimidation, or sustained failure to correct defective conditions after notice. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–104; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 284–285.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and defines it as protecting tenants from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the premises. The court holds that repeated, preventable flooding due to the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and explains that liability does not require intent but extends at least to reckless conduct. This supports the proposition that serious interference with use and enjoyment—including sustained failure to correct defective conditions after notice—violates quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.… [Gem] violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions … and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code can support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when they materially affect the health or safety of occupants. See, e.g., Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) (housing code violations and failure to remedy conditions support tenant remedies and rent abatement); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (code violations and landlord inaction after notice constitute substantial interference).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is about breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement; it does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it frame the landlord’s liability in terms of breach of quiet enjoyment. While the court repeatedly ties habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and discusses tenant remedies and rent abatement, it does so under warranty and G.L. c. 239, § 8A, not under c. 186, § 14. Thus, using Berman as authority that sanitary code violations can support a c. 186, § 14 quiet enjoyment claim is inaccurate.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969)… When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations… As was the case in Hemingway, this statute provides for rent withholding, not rent abatement; but, as in Hemingway, we choose to permit a rent abatement as a matter of common law.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code can support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when they materially affect the health or safety of occupants. See, e.g., Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) (housing code violations and failure to remedy conditions support tenant remedies and rent abatement); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (code violations and landlord inaction after notice constitute substantial interference).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations only in the context of warranty of habitability and rent abatement, and notes that most conditions had minimal impact. It does not analyze G.L. c. 186, § 14, breach of quiet enjoyment, or hold that code violations and landlord inaction constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. The proposition attributes a quiet enjoyment holding to Young v. Patukonis that is not present in the text provided.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.”

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s adverse treatment of Plaintiff and decision not to renew the tenancy, following Plaintiff’s report of code violations, is consistent with retaliatory conduct and coercive interference with Plaintiff’s statutory rights. See G.L. c. 186, § 18 (prohibiting retaliation for tenant’s contact with housing inspectors); Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983) (retaliatory actions by landlord after tenant complaints can violate statutory tenant protections and quiet enjoyment).
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. O’Brien concerns a public housing authority’s eviction of a tenant for permitting illegal drug activity in her apartment and analyzes whether there was good cause under G.L. c. 121B, § 32, the nature of the tenancy, adequacy of notices, and availability of defenses. It does not involve any claim that the landlord acted in retaliation for the tenant’s exercise of statutory rights, does not interpret G.L. c. 186, § 18, and does not discuss retaliatory or coercive interference with a tenant’s contact with housing inspectors. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition about retaliatory non‑renewal following code‑violation complaints.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “O’Brien’s eviction is founded upon ‘good cause reasonably related to the protection of some legitimate interest of the public landlord.’ Spence v. Reeder, 382 Mass. at 420… As we stated earlier, O’Brien was not without fault in that she knew of and tolerated Harris’ misconduct. The judge was not in error in concluding that the defenses were not available to O’Brien.”
